item.title: Building Speakers
item.description:
Some time ago, we bought a new TV, as the old one was making a significant contribution to our electricity costs. It was also time to replace the old PA speakers I had been using in the living room by a more visually and technically elegant solution. Unfortunately, using only the speakers built into the TV was not an option, as you can clearly hear the lack of available space.

After some market research, visits to stores, various online forums and so forth, I decided on a simple, self-assembled soundbar.

What I don’t like about off-the-shelf soundbars

Although I’ve been interested in speaker construction for some time, I initially wanted to buy a soundbar in a store or order one online. I noticed:

1. Soundbars are very difficult to compare with each other

The prices of soundbars cover a fairly wide price range. From around 39 euros to four-figure sums, everything is included. However, the advertising campaigners manage to attach various ingenious sound technologies, special modes or virtual surround sound to all the speakers. All products impress with incomparable sound quality, pulsating bass and other outstanding features. Apparently, all soundbars are top class. However, there is no detailed measurement or description of the frequency response or other reliable characteristics such as the signal-to-noise ratio of the soundbars. The origin of the different prices therefore remains a mystery, at least to me.

2. Where do all these ratings come from?

There are plenty of product reviews, (paid) product tests and comparisons on the Internet. However, I am suspicious of reviews from buyers, because even the cheapest products are often described as having a superb sound. Product tests also seem to be positively biased, with the scale of sound quality often only ranging from good to extremely good. In hi-fi forums, however, the exact opposite seems to be the case: All purchasable soundbars are complete crap.

3. I can’t repair a store bought soundbar

While a purchasable soundbar has all sorts of useful and less useful features, this complexity also makes it less repairable. A lot of electronics are built into a compact plastic housing with minimized manufacturing costs. Digital signal processors ensure a system sound quality that could not be achieved without algorithms. Technically, of course, it is impressive to get the maximum out of the built-in components, but this makes the speaker more complicated than necessary. In addition, the sound is often transmitted wirelessly if there are separate speaker cabinets. If the subwoofer doesn’t connect properly to the system at some point, I’m completely out of luck.

Even with a (passive) self-built loudspeaker cabinet as described below, there is of course no alternative but to use an amplifier. However, due to the low power required, many used audio amplifiers, amplifiers from disused stereo systems and small amplifier kits from the Internet can be used. So I can get away cheaply and am flexible in terms of functionality.

Building a MiniACL soundbar

I need a construction plan so that I can assemble a soundbar myself. A randomly assembled speaker with any dimensions and shape will not sound good in the vast majority of cases. When developing new speaker geometries, simulations and numerous calculations are necessary. Since I don’t see myself in a position to do this, I ordered a kit from Udo Wohlgemuth. This gives me access to a fully developed and tested design. The speaker kit consists of speaker chassis, insulating wool, electrical components for the crossovers, cables, connection terminals, screws and bass reflex tubes. The only thing missing is the wood. I opted for inexpensive coarse chipboard, which not only has good acoustic properties, but is also very cheap.

With the help of the supplied construction plan, I cut all the wooden parts to size using a hand-held circular saw.

I marked out the openings for the speaker chassis, connection terminals and bass reflex tubes with an old pair of circular compasses and cut them out with a jigsaw.

I then assembled the speaker housing step by step and glued it together with the help of wood glue. By the way, expensive wood glue that doesn’t require clamps or weights is another advertising lie, or I was too stupid.

Several chambers with identical air volumes divide the inside of the speaker enclosure. This principle of the so-called Acoustic Chamber Line was developed by Udo Wohlgemuth.

After drying, the components can be installed in the speaker housing. You don’t need to be a professional with a soldering iron to connect the few components. A hot glue gun is used to fix the components in place.

After installing the electrical components and some insulating wool, the speaker is ready.

The quality increase when watching TV or listening to music compared to the internal speakers of our TV is enormous. To quantify the difference in quality, I borrowed a lab microphone and a recording device from work. I measured the frequency response of the new soundbar, the TV and the laptop. However, I realized that I would first have to become familiar with the topic in order to make a proper comparison. Maybe one day…

item.title: Reparing Shoes
item.description:
When I started working after graduation, my girlfriend told me that it was time to buy some decent shoes for everyday wear. Until then, I wore random trainers or low shoes, which did their job until they fell apart into various individual parts. Anyone who mentions the words “shoes” and “duct tape” to my mom can expect some adventurous stories from my youth.

In a random shoe store of a major chain, after a short search, we spotted what seemed to be the ideal pair of shoes. Reduced from 80 to 50 euros, brown leather with sneaker soles and comfortable. She liked it, so here we go.

After a year in which I wore the shoes regularly, but not daily, first disappointment spread. The sole of the shoes was completely worn in some areas, a plastic skeleton under the rubber came out piece by piece. This annoyed me for one reason in particular: the leather was still in good shape despite moderate care. Throwing it away was therefore out of the question initially. A local cobbler took care of the problem (“Holy shit”) and was finally able to glue new sneaker soles on my shoes for a total of 40 euros. With that, my shoes were initially fit again.

Unfortunately, a few weeks after the repair, the inner lining of the shoes in the area of the heel dissolved piece by piece into the air. Simply sewing it back on at the existing seam was not possible, the inner lining would have had to be completely replaced. Although the leather was still in great condition, I gave up at that point.

A few months later, my little toes started drilling their way through the thin fabric of my running shoes. Throwing them away directly was out of the question, so I made two patches out of old clothes and sewed them to the shoes by hand over the holes. This really does not look great, but I still use the shoes today. Because again, all other parts of the shoes are perfectly fine.

Inspired by the idea to put more on sustainability and repairability in shoes, I started to research. Because also my black leather shoes, which I wear on business trips, could use a little better care and maintenance. After all, I bought them long time ago for the senior prom. At a dealer for shoemaking supplies in Dortmund, I was able to buy a starter set for shoe repairs. At the roadside I found an old metal toolbox, which I now use as a shoe repair box after a quick rust removal.

With the help of the tools I completely resoled my black leather shoes. In Amsterdam I later bought some red leather shoes second hand. These also got new soles. There is hope that my current shoes last much longer compared to the past.

item.title: Baking Meatloaf
item.description:
A while back, I had the loose idea to only eat meat products where I was involved in the production as much as possible within my capabilities. As a first step, I bought the necessary cuts from our local, self-slaughtering butcher. Making my own salami didn’t work in a first attempt (the mold took over), so I wanted to try something easier. On youtube I found a good tutorial on how to make meatloaf.

Cutting up and mincing the pork shoulder, back fat, and pork cheek was an unusual experience. Chicken breast is quite a different thing.

The meatloaf was fantastic, perhaps because the fat percentage was very high. I gave a few slices away to family, and froze the rest. The meatloaf also made a great bread topping.

Since I’m currently trying to eat vegan, there is no more meatloaf for now. But I can highly recommend to give this a try.

item.title: Sewing
item.description:
My mother-in-law gave me an old sewing machine that she no longer needed. I was thrilled. An Elna Lotus ZZ from Switzerland, about 50 years old. The housing is made of metal. At home, however, it ended up in the closet for a while. Until now.

After many attempts, I was able to thread the machine correctly and sew a first seam. The adventure begins.

Level 1

Do you know those colorful foam dishcloths you can buy in the supermarket? After a while they crumble all over the place and you have to buy new ones. So what could be more obvious than sewing rags for cleaning, washing up and personal hygiene? The material was old towels and shirts that had been sorted out.

Level 2

New boxer shorts were needed. With the help of a free pattern I have now sewn together six copies. For the first I needed five hours, for the last two and a half. This means that the financial value per hour of work is higher than that of brewing beer!

Level 3

For years, my lightweight 40 liter backpack has been my travel companion. Because it is slim cut and has an opening only at the top, however, you always have to unpack a bunch of stuff, even to reach small items. Since buying new is out of question, we try to solve this problem with a zipper bought on the Internet for about 3 euros.

After carefully marking the center line, I separated the front of the backpack with scissors. Now there is no turning back.

To prevent the cut fabric from tearing, I first sew off the edges. With the boxer shorts this is trivial, but with the already sewn-together backpack it’s a challenge, especially at the bottom of the future zipper. Constantly the backpack gets stuck somewhere and hinders me.

Before cutting the front, the two edges of the fabric touched. Now that a zipper with its width is sewn between the edges of the fabric, the two sides are a little too wide. Therefore, I sew both sides inwards. That also looks better. Theoretically.

After sewing in the zipper, I need to sew the bottom end to the backpack. I do this by hand because the fabrics are too thick at this point and I can’t really sew with the machine at this position anyway. Well…

Even if it is not visually perfect, the experiment worked and I do not have to buy another backpack after all.

item.title: Brewing Beer
item.description:
Why brew your own beer?

You don’t save money, for the price of the ingredients you can buy a finished beer in the supermarket. On top of that, it takes about 8 hours of work for 20 liters.

It tastes very good, and it makes a great gift. But in the end, there is one reason above all to brew your own beer: Cause it works.

item.title: Growing Rye
item.description:
Since we have our own flour mill, I have been fascinated by grain. Small kernels that can be stored for a long time and become seed again when needed. In 2021 I decided to grow summer rye in our garden on 10 sqm. Nearly 3 kg of whole grain flour was the result.

After the heads had dried indoors for a few weeks, I threshed the rye with the help of an electric drill. Then the grains were laboriously separated from the husks and straw residues. In this youtube video I have documented these steps.

Based on the good experience with the rye, I decided to plant sweet corn in 2022. The straw from the rye is reused as mulch.
